title: Wimpole Hall Walking Route

images.title: Airwolfhound from  Hertfordshire, UK [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Wimpole Hall

images.title: Elliott Simpson / Wimpole Hall, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The view from the Hall looking towards the Folly (seen between the trees) - the perimeter fence for the Estate is hidden in a ditch which runs just beyond the trees giving the impression that there is no boundary between the Hall and the Folly.

images.title: Elliott Simpson / Wimpole Hall, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Wimpole Hall the grounds, looking west - the wall which surrounds the estate is hidden in a ditch between the pillars in the centre of the photo and this gives the impression that the estate extends to the horizon

images.title: Elliott Simpson / Wimpole Hall, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The ditch in the foreground serves as a continuation of the perimeter wall while the view from the garden side gives the impression that the estate continues without boundaries to the horizon.

images.title: ray sullivan / Wimpole Hall Estate, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Wimpole Hall Estate. Numerous sheep & cattle graze the grounds of the estate.

images.title: Tim Tregenza [CC BY-SA 3.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Wimpole Hall Stables

images.title: Rictor Norton  & David Allen from London, United Kingdom [CC BY 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Glasshouse

images.title: Rictor Norton  & David Allen from London, United Kingdom [CC BY 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: In the walled garden

description: This 17th century country house near Cambridge is surrounded by 3,000 acres of parkland and farmland. There are miles of walking paths taking you to the walled garden with glasshouse and vegetable plots, the glorious parterre with 12,000 plants and the delightful pleasure gardens. There's also the opportunity for a quiet woodland stroll through Cobbs Wood where you can look out for eight species of woodland bat. The site includes Home Farm with its donkeys, shire horses and rare breed livestock. It's great for families as children can groom the donkeys and have a drive on a mini tractor. There are also 18th century farm buildings including  cart sheds, stables, cattle yards and deer pens. You can also explore the house with its grand rooms and collections of furniture, porcelain and paintings. If you would like to continue your walk you could pick up the Wimpole Way and head north to visit the Hardwick Wood nature reserve. The long distance trail will eventually lead you into Cambridge.
